1.53.text:
- Katie Schumaker: Today,
we are pleased to introduce
Lori Bessler,

3.54.text:
as part of the
Wisconsin Historical Museum's

9.31.text:
the Wisconsin Historical Society
Library Archives since 1988.

13.58.text:
She is a reference librarian
and outreach coordinator.

16.35.text:
Lori has lectured throughout
Wisconsin and the Midwest

18.69.text:
on genealogical topics
for over 25 years,

21.59.text:
and has been researching family
history for over 35 years.

25.03.text:
She specializes in breaking
down brick walls

29.50.text:
Here today to share some of
the many resources available

32.83.text:
to researchers at the Wisconsin
Historical Society,

35.57.text:
please join me in
welcoming Lori Bessler.

48.11.text:
It is kind of an interesting
day out there weather-wise.

51.68.text:
I've been with the Society
a long time.

55.76.text:
I've talked about our
collections many, many times,

59.63.text:
but I always enjoy
telling more about it.

62.09.text:
There's such depth to the
Historical Society collections,

65.80.text:
and they are just hiding on
the other side of State Street

69.70.text:
So, the collection has over
four million items in it,

74.21.text:
most of which have to do
with North American history.

78.61.text:
So we cover
all the United States

80.05.text: and all the provinces of Canada.

85.29.text:
No matter where your ancestry
is coming from or going to

89.12.text:
in North America,
we do have materials for you.

94.56.text:
In the Library, we have
mostly published materials.

98.16.text:
In the Archives, there are
more original documents.

101.60.text:
We are the state archives
for the State of Wisconsin,

104.10.text:
and so we have a lot of
materials that have come from

109.54.text:
as well as private collections
that people have donated,

113.01.text:
or that we've obtained
in various ways.

115.08.text:
The Library also
has very accessible hours.

121.82.text:
We have our hours
posted on our website.

123.72.text:
I'm going to give you a review
of our website in a few minutes.

127.69.text:
The collections for both the
Library and the Archives

132.43.text:
If you used our different
catalogs a couple years ago,

135.37.text: that changed about a year ago.

137.47.text: In May, I think it was.

139.27.text:
And so everything was
deposited into one catalog,

142.14.text:
which makes it a lot
easier in a lot of ways,

144.38.text:
but change is always
interesting, too.

147.51.text:
So having the archivists
and the librarians

150.55.text:
help you through this
is really core,

152.25.text:
and we try to make ourselves
pretty accessible

154.95.text: in a lot of different ways.

156.16.text:
You can contact us
by e-mail, by phone,

160.69.text:
I do a lot of phone
consultations with people

162.93.text:
from around the country who have
connections to Wisconsin.

166.83.text:
And people who are in this area,
who are coming in,

169.97.text:
or anywhere in Wisconsin
traveling to see us,

173.11.text:
I have consultations with them,
as well,

175.24.text:
to help them identify the paper
trail that will shed more light

179.01.text:
into the family history
that they're researching.

182.92.text:
On-site, in the library,
and in the archives,

185.35.text:
we have technology that can help
you capture what you do find.

189.26.text:
So if you come to do
research at the Society,

192.29.text:
then you're going to want
to bring a flash drive.
[chuckle]

198.46.text: that can be used in the library,

202.23.text:
It is a more secure area
in the archives

204.84.text:
because you're dealing with
a lot of original documents.

207.54.text:
You have printers and scanners
so that if you come in

212.51.text:
and you have a book and
there is a portion of the book

216.32.text:
you want to scan to your flash
drive, it's awesome. [chuckle]

219.52.text:
It makes it a lot easier
to capture that information

222.45.text:
then take it home
and read it when you get home.

225.66.text:
If you do make prints,
there is a 25¢ print fee.

230.33.text:
All of those details are
found on our website.

234.73.text:
And then, also, calling before
you come is a good idea as well.

239.04.text:
Let me show you a couple
things on our website.

244.04.text:
And if you look lower
down on the screen,

248.01.text:
you have all these
different tabs.

250.08.text:
You have Research
Your Family History;

251.62.text:
Discover Your Community History;
Explore Our Collections;

257.76.text:
Visit Wisconsin Museums
and Historic Sites;

260.06.text:
and Preserve Your
Homes and Properties.

262.80.text:
I'm going to cover a couple
of these different buttons.

267.47.text:
right away comes up with a
search box.

269.34.text:
And I really encourage
you to take a moment,

272.14.text:
breathe before you
start putting names in.

275.98.text:
It's always important,
especially with sites like this

278.04.text:
and very much especially with
"Family Search" and "Ancestry",

282.11.text:
that you understand what
you're actually looking at.

288.45.text:
Browse All Items in Family
History Resources.

291.42.text:
It gives you a list of all the
different types of items...

295.69.text:
all the different types of
collections

297.76.text: that are being indexed in this.

299.93.text:
And so each one of these
has criteria to them.

304.84.text:
They have a wonderful
amount of information,

308.11.text:
An example: the
Birth Index Record.

313.88.text:
It's an index to
birth records we happen to have

319.08.text:
They're only records that were
sent on to the state level...

322.35.text:
to the state by
the Records Office.

324.99.text:
And so it is possible that the
County Register of Deeds Office

328.83.text:
has something
that's not at the state level.

334.13.text:
and reference archivists
can help you.

336.34.text:
If you went into this index
and you did not find something,

339.61.text:
then it's really important for
you to contact us and say,

343.38.text:
What else can I find
this information on?"

345.38.text:
And we can explain the details
of the paper trail

348.71.text:
that exist out there for your
ancestors, depending on,

351.18.text:
you know, the criteria of
where they're from,

353.99.text: what time or era are they from.

357.36.text:
And so when you look at that
index ...

365.40.text: they all have criteria to them.

366.90.text:
Take your time to
understand each part.

369.84.text:
If you do find an entry
in the records...

373.31.text: I have this one example here...

375.27.text: What you can do is choose to

377.98.text:
go online
and actually buy it from us.

383.28.text:
Or if you live in the area,
write down the information

386.75.text:
it tells you
in the reference details,

388.89.text:
make a print of this, screen
shot
of it, whatever it is,

392.12.text:
and then, when you come to the
Society,

393.79.text:
you can make a print of this
for 25¢.

396.30.text:
So there are
those kinds of deals. [chuckles]

400.90.text:
There's that kind of research
technique or tactics

404.54.text: that we can help you with,

406.31.text:
as you call us ahead of time or
when you come in.

409.14.text:
Set up a time that you
can talk to one of us,

411.98.text:
and we can explain
these kinds of details.

418.15.text:
When you do have a bunch
of hits on the list,

421.45.text:
on the right--
the left side, rather--

423.92.text:
you can actually start
to filter down,

426.43.text:
down to a certain era
or down to a certain location.

429.83.text:
So find out someone was born in
Brown County in 1842 or 1840.

436.13.text:
Eighteen hundred to 1900,
I can choose 1840 to '49.

441.27.text:
So if you used to use the index
before we had changed it,

445.65.text:
You should be able to filter
down by location and by year

449.12.text:
and be able to see
exactly what there is.

450.92.text:
This is especially important
when you're dealing,

454.75.text:
name changes and
misinterpretation of names.

458.32.text:
Someone else is writing your
name

460.13.text:
most of the time in public
records.

462.36.text:
Someone else is interpreting
what you're saying

464.03.text:
and spelling it the way they
want it spelled.

466.06.text: Or they're going to spell it.

467.77.text:
So what you can do when you
get the best amount of hits,

470.60.text:
you can then sort
it alphabetically.

474.21.text:
So this index has
become more accessible,

477.11.text:
more usable to a lot
of people in that way.

479.48.text:
I will go back a
couple pages here.

488.12.text:
Another item in here
is Video Tutorials.

492.02.text: The information I just gave you

493.76.text:
is all in different tutorials
here.

497.76.text: All you have to do is...

500.47.text:
Most of them
are less than six minutes.

504.87.text: I was telling you how to find...

507.34.text:
Learn about the collections
included in the index.

510.94.text:
That's how I explained
how you find that list.

513.38.text:
And the second one is learn how
to find a name in our index

517.28.text:
from the home page, which
is the very first page.

520.29.text:
They have a search
box at the top,

522.19.text:
and that explains how you can
manipulate your search that way.

525.19.text: Then, how to find a name

527.29.text:
through our Research Your Family
History page specifically.

530.76.text:
And most importantly, how to
search the index without a name,

536.77.text:
I encourage you to try that
kind of strategy

541.17.text: Try a search without a name.

542.54.text:
Try putting in a
location and a date.

545.28.text: It gives you a bigger snapshot

547.45.text:
of that location where your
ancestors were.

549.82.text:
So all of those are
different, like I said,

552.82.text:
research strategies that
are important to take.

555.86.text:
This whole thing we call
genealogy, family history,

559.86.text: It is not a quick trip.

561.53.text:
No matter what "Ancestry" says,
it's not a quick trip.

564.56.text: You don't want it to be.

566.17.text:
You want to keep going deeper
and deeper and deeper.

569.13.text:
And that's what our
staff helps you to do.

571.90.text:
Believe me, I meet with so many
different people, and I'm like,

576.61.text:
I can't wait to take them on!"
[laughing]

579.95.text:
There's got to be
something else.

583.15.text:
The gentleman had looked at all
kinds of different materials.

587.29.text:
What about this?
What about that?

588.65.text:
So there's always
another level to go to.

591.42.text:
Finally with that gentleman
it was: You know what?

594.09.text:
You can add some more general
history to your family.

596.93.text:
You can look at where they're
from and what was going on

600.07.text:
at the time they were
living in that location.

603.74.text: They lived in this one town,

605.20.text:
a tornado came through at the
time they were living there.

608.81.text:
I don't know how it missed
the family oral history,

613.78.text:
So it's important to look
for how deep you can go.

617.92.text:
And again that's how we
can help you with that.

622.45.text:
For those who are
living far away,

628.79.text:
is an obituary search service
that we have.

631.80.text:
So if you are unable to come
here to do the research,

634.40.text: then you can go on this website

636.20.text:
and actually order an obituary
search.

638.47.text:
Now we took our lead from the
Minnesota Historical Society,

641.57.text:
which is a great
institution as well.

644.64.text:
They do an obituary
search as well.

646.71.text:
We actually do two
newspapers when we search.

650.82.text:
second only to the Library of
Congress.

653.45.text: Only to the Library of Congress.

657.29.text:
What that means is that we have
any Wisconsin newspaper

661.23.text:
that has ever been uncovered,
we have copies of.

664.53.text: Most of which is on microfilm.

666.50.text:
And then also if you
can't get to here,

668.73.text:
then our microfilm loans
to other libraries,

672.80.text:
So there's that accessibility
to materials

675.44.text:
is also really core
to our services.

678.24.text:
So if people do need us
to find the obituary,

680.78.text:
then they can put that
on order at our website.

687.15.text:
a big part is access
to our online catalog.

691.96.text:
This is THE list of what we
have, which is really important.

695.46.text:
When you're trying to do
research you want to know,

699.30.text:
You can do all of this searching
from home before you come.

703.74.text:
Here's an example:
if you're looking to see

705.34.text:
if we have any family histories
that have been published.

709.11.text:
I'm not talking about the trees
that are on "Ancestry."

711.31.text:
I mean people have written
a book of some sort,

714.21.text:
and we have gathered that book
or it's been donated to us.

717.85.text:
What you would do is
you would put in a name.

723.02.text:
And then use two different words
when you're searching, okay?

726.39.text:
Do the surname
and the word "genealogy."

730.26.text: You can see I got five hits.

736.17.text: And you see I got 10 hits.

741.41.text:
So when you're using
an online catalog,

745.08.text:
Make sure you're trying
different terms, okay?

748.38.text:
Try the surnames of people
who married INTO the family.

752.98.text:
a family genealogy
that we linked into.

756.12.text:
It's called "For the
Starr Family," S-T-A-R-R.

759.86.text:
There's one little paragraph
about the fact

762.39.text:
that the Cook
went INTO the Starr family,

765.83.text:
and it gave the maiden name
of a woman.

768.40.text:
I could not find
that maiden name anywhere else.

770.97.text:
It must've been published
around the time

774.37.text:
They provided that information,
and it was not located

777.51.text:
anywhere else that I found
in the public record.

779.54.text: So that's important to look at.

781.71.text:
Another item:
when you pull up an item,

788.89.text:
many of our family histories
are still under copyright,

793.53.text:
or assumed to be under
copyright, published since 1923.

798.53.text: We have a lot of people...

800.03.text:
because we have a contract with
Google,

a lot of our
books have been digitized.

803.70.text:
Well, they pull it up in Google,

calls saying, "I'd like to buy

813.14.text:
We keep the books so that you
can access them later,"

817.55.text: So one of the things is that

819.99.text:
if it is a digital book,
a couple of points, okay?

One is that familysearch.org
and Google

828.29.text:
are two of the websites I go to
most frequently

831.16.text:
to check if a book has been

Familysearch.org is the website
for the Latter-day Saints,

Their website is huge,
and I will give you

a little bit of a survey

842.97.text: What you would do in this case.

844.71.text:
I want the "Wiseman
Genealogy and Biography."

You can see
I have the call number

If I look lower down,

856.19.text:
to the digital copy

That's a combination of

who have gone through this

865.13.text:
their books accessible through

869.43.text:
And so that gives me free

872.70.text:
And I will tell you what I've

of the books that any branch of

879.21.text:
been listed in that is out

882.15.text:
I save the whole book, and have

external hard drive and in the
hard drive of my laptop... as

889.35.text:
well now I'm looking in

892.12.text:
because there are so many ways

895.19.text:
And there are strategies with
saving information too that,

898.50.text:
but I could go on all day

903.14.text:
Okay, so again,
look for those items

905.77.text: that are in that online catalog.

907.87.text:
See if there is a digital
copy

910.44.text:
you can just go into and

Every fall and spring we hold

usually at Memorial Library on

933.63.text:

Preparing for a Trip to the

is our Area Research Centers

Basically, what this means is

across the state,

that cover the counties that are

And what you find is that

So if I'm researching

I'm going to be contacting

that is located

So, again, throughout all of

I'm kind of covering

1167.50.text:
they all have depth to them.
All right?

1170.87.text:
if someone is looking
for naturalization records,

I, as a reference librarian,

1176.97.text:
"Family Search" has digitized a

1180.01.text:
and where you would find

The archivists who are at

they know their collections,

So using them as a staff to

1202.47.text:
documents that are not always

that's really important and

So it's important to understand

I worry a lot because "Ancestry"

and we can tell you all the

but don't forget that the staff

We have so many people who can

to understand the records
